text.tspan: A strategic planning technique analyzing strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats faced by a product, project or organization.

text.data-name: ・What have we or our product excelled at in the past? ・What resources, technology or skills do we have that others don’t?
text.tspan: What have we or our product excelled at in the past?
What resources, technology or skills do we have that others don’t?

text.data-name: ・What is the future market demand for the product or service. ・What technology has opened new doors?
text.tspan: What is the future market demand for the product or service.
What technology has opened new doors?

text.data-name: ・What was the principle cause for past failures? ・What criticism have we received from others?
text.tspan: What was the principle cause for past failures?
What criticism have we received from others?

text.data-name: ・What changes have occurred in your industry that could result in lost business? ・Which competitors are your biggest threat?
text.tspan: What changes have occurred in your industry that could result in lost business?
Which competitors are your biggest threat?

tspan.tspan: A SWOT Analysis is a method to evaluate strengths (S),
weaknesses (W), opportunities (O) and threats (T). A process
first developed at Harvard Business School in the 1950s, it can
also be used by designers, PMs and engineers to evaluate
products, services and strategies. Those four factors evaluate
both internal and external factors related to a specific project,
service or strategy. Also, a great exercise is to run a SWOT
Analysis of your competition.
Determine the objective. Decide on a key product, service
or strategy to analyze.
List up strengths. Strengths are internal, positive
attributes. These are things that are within your control.
List up weaknesses. These are negative factors that
detract from your strengths. These are things that you might
need to improve on to be competitive.
List up opportunities. These are external factors in your
business environment that are likely to contribute to your
success.
List up opportunities threats. These are external factors
that you have no control over. You may want to consider
putting in place contingency plans for dealing them if they
occur.
With your SWOT analysis complete, you’re ready to convert
it into a real design strategy.
